Butenes are considered as important olefinic building block to produce fuels/fuel additives and commodity chemicals. In the present investigation, selective dehydration of 1-butanol to butenes was studied in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor using various silica-supported heteropolyacid (HPA) catalysts such as phosphotungstic acid (PTA), silicotungstic acid (STA), phosphomolybdic acid (PMA), and silicomolybdic acid (SMA) as the solid acid catalysts. The physicochemical properties of these HPA were determined by BET, powder XRD, FTIR, NH3-TPD, and Py-FTIR. The acid strength and Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) acid ratio were increased with higher loading of HPA on silica. The nature of HPA (addenda and hetero atom) and loading of HPA are important factors for the dehydration of 1-butanol and selectivity towards butenes. PTA and STA showed superior catalytic activity than PMA and SMA. The reaction temperature and WHSV also strongly affected the butanol conversion and selectivity of butenes. The selectivity of di-n‑butyl ether decreases with the rising temperature from 523 K to 623 K. The isomerization of 1-butene leading to the formation of other butene isomers depends on the HPA loading, temperature, and WHSV. The presence of molybdenum addendum atom in PMA and SMA promotes dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, leading to the formation of various light hydrocarbons. The 20PTA/SiO2 catalyst afforded 99.8% selectivity towards butenes at quantitative conversion of 1-butanol, whereas the 20STA/SiO2 catalyst gave nearly 97.0% conversion of 1-butanol and 99.9% butenes selectivity at 673 K, 37.4 h−1 of WHSV. The oligomers of these light olefins are important feedstocks to produce lubricants, motor fuels, dyes, detergents, and fuel additives [2]. In recent times, studies on the dehydration of butanol to butenes (isobutene,1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) have drawn attention due to rising demand for the petrochemical feedstocks [3–5]. The butenes oligomerize to fuels and fuel additives over suitable solid acid catalysts [1,2,5–7]. For example, 1-butene (1-BUY) is used to produce oligomers and polymeric materials via oligomerization reaction and/or co-polymerization reaction with more reactive lighter olefins like ethylene and propylene [8,9]. Dimerization of butenes gives oxygen and sulfur-free fuel additives that enhances the octane number of gasoline fuels [10,11]. Production of butenes from bio-butanol (produced from renewable and sustainable feedstocks) has economic and environmental benefits. Butanol is used as a solvent and a raw material for the production of various classes of products including polymers and plasticizers. [12,13]. Butanol can also be used as a fuel additive as well as a drop-in fuel because of its higher energy density than ethanol, less ignition problems, and cleaner emission [14,15]. 1-Butanol is produced commercially by the hydroformylation of propene followed by hydrogenation, which makes the process dependent on petroleum. Rising population and improvement in quality of life increases the demand for petrochemicals-based commodity chemicals, which stimulate growing consumption of fossil fuel feedstock resulting in fast depletion of fossil fuels and global warming. Considering all these factors, it is essential to choose alternate sustainable renewable resources to produce chemical feedstocks, which are presently produced from petroleum. Recently, biomass-derived butanol isomers have attracted considerable attention as renewable chemical feedstock to produce butenes and cater to the demands of petrochemical industry [16]. With the rising demand of butanol, the production of biobutanol from inexpensive biomass via biochemical, thermochemical, and chemo-catalytic routes have huge commercial potential [17]. The production of butenes by the dehydration of 1-butanol over different catalysts has been studied [4,16,18–20]. Dehydration of butanol isomers over zeolites of different topologies, such as MFI, FAU, and MOR, was investigated to produce butenes. Among these catalysts, MFI zeolite showed better stability even after 48 h of reaction [21]. The microkinetic modeling of 1-butanol dehydration reaction studies over H-ZSM-5, H-ZSM-22, and H-FER were studied and highest turnover frequency was reported over H-ZSM-5 catalyst [22]. The dehydration of 1-butanol over Theta-1 (63), Ferrierite (20), ZSM-23 (68), and ZSM-5 (280) catalysts (673 K, GHSV 5200 h−1) gave 68.6, 82.5, 62.4, and 24.7 wt.% yield of butenes, respectively, at quantitative conversion of 1-butanol [23]. In another study, it was reported that C1 C3 hydrocarbons, DBE, and other higher hydrocarbons were also formed along with butenes owing to the presence of Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst. In this case, the selectivity to butenes reached nearly 75% at 523 K and 15 h−1 WHSV [16]. A combination of experimental and theoretical studies of butanol dehydration over H-MFI, H-FAU, and H-MOR catalysts reported the formation of higher hydrocarbons and olefins due to oligomerization and cracking reactions [21]. Dehydration of butanol over acidic ZSM-5 (280) produced 24.0 wt.% yield of butenes along with 37.2 wt.% C3 C5 olefins due to cracking reaction on the Brønsted acid sites of the ZSM-5 catalyst [23]. In a different study, ZSM-5 showed good dehydration activity with low butenes selectivity due to the formation of other gaseous hydrocarbons and hydrocarbons of high molecular weight [24]. To improve the selectivity of butenes further, efforts are being directed towards tuning the acidity of zeolite H-ZSM-5 catalyst by strategies like desilication, dealumination, etc. For example, phosphorous and lanthanum-phosphorus modified H-ZSM-5 catalysts were investigated for ethanol dehydration reaction and reported higher ethylene selectivity and stability of the catalyst [25,26]. Dehydration of butanol to butenes using various non-zeolite-based solid acid catalysts, such as γ-alumina, SiO2-Al2O3, tungstated zirconia, and heteropolyacids (HPAs), have also been reported [17–22]. Among these solid acid catalysts, HPA catch much interests due to their economical and environmentally friendly nature and possess higher Brønsted acidity than oxide and zeolite catalysts [23,27–33]. Both supported and bulk (unsupported) HPA catalysts have been used in many solid acids catalyzed reactions such as isomerization of alkenes and alkanes, dehydration of alcohols, and also used as oxidation catalysts [32–34]. HPA catalysts are considered promising due to their favorable physicochemical properties (e.g., high thermal stability), environmentally benign nature (e.g., noncorrosive, nontoxic), and operational simplicity (e.g., convenient separation, recyclability) [32,35]. HPA materials have several advantages and favorable characteristics in designing efficient catalysts such as i) catalysts design at atomic/molecular level with tunable activity, ii) pseudo liquid behavior and shape selective, iii) unique basicity of polyanion [36]. Specifically, HPA catalysts are used in acid and oxidation reactions because of their high proton mobility and their capability to accept or release electrons [29]. In addition, properties like strong Brønsted acidity, well-defined structure, and the possibility to modify its acid-base properties by varying its constituent elements (heteroatom, addenda atoms, and counter cations) potentiates its catalytic nature towards the selective oxidation reactions and also in the transformation of methanol to hydrocarbons [37–40]. HPA catalysts, especially phosphotungstic acid (PTA) and silicotungstic acid (STA), which possess high acidity, are used for the double bond isomerization of 1-BUY and cis-2-butene (cis-2-BUY) [41]. The skeletal isomerization of n-butane to isobutane has been investigated over HPA catalysts and compared with HZSM-5 catalyst. The higher selectivity observed over HPA catalysts was due to their stronger acidity [42]. HPA catalysts are known for both surface, and bulk phase (pseudo liquid phase) catalysis based on polarity, size of reactants, and reaction parameters maintained during reaction [36,43–45]. In regular heterogeneous catalysis, reactants may be adsorbed on the two-dimensional surface and pore walls of the solid catalysts. In contrast, in the case of HPA catalysts, reactants also absorb in the bulk phase (solid behaves like three-dimensional solution medium). The reactant molecule penetrates into the solid lattice and absorbs between the polyanions (not in a polyanion) in the ionic crystal and reacts inside, followed by desorption of the products from the bulk phase. PTA catalyst showed high catalytic activity for large polar compounds by absorption in the bulk phase despite having low surface area as reported in the literature [36,43–45]. However, some of its major disadvantages are poor thermal stability, low surface area, inaccessibility of reactants to the active sites, and leach easily in polar [46,47]. Therefore, higher dispersion of HPA on suitable supports enhances their surface area, thermal stability and also makes them eco-friendly. The HPA supported on suitable supports (SiO2, ZrO2, zeolites, activated carbon, etc.) were studied for many solid acids catalyzed reactions [33,35,46–49]. Among the various supports used, silica is preferred to support HPA because of its good chemical and thermal stability, lesser acidity, tunable surface area, and porosity [48,50–52]. The pore size of silica has a strong effect on the dispersion of HPA, catalytic activity, and selectivity to desired product [52]. The supported H3PW12O40 (PTA), H4SiW12O40 (STA), and H3PMo12O40 (PMA) were employed for the dehydration of secondary alcohols, and higher dehydration activity was reported for these HPAs [35]. Recent studies have investigated the effect of various HPAs (H3PW12O40 and H4SiW12O40) loading on silica to dehydration of methanol and ethanol [50]. Dehydration of methanol and ethanol was studied extensively, where dimethyl ether (DME) and diethyl ether (DEE) were found to form as major products at lower temperatures (kinetically controlled reaction). High reaction temperature enhanced the selectivity of ethene at the expense of DEE (thermodynamically controlled reaction) [32,50,53,54]. In the present investigation, several silica-supported HPA catalysts such as PTA, STA, PMA, and SMA (silicomolybdic acid, H4SiMo12O40) were prepared by wet impregnation method to generate different strengths and nature of acidic sites. The prepared silica-supported HPA catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, FTIR, Pyridine FTIR, and NH3-TPD. The silica-supported HPA catalysts were examined for the selective dehydration of 1-butanol to butenes in a continuous fixed bed reactor. The effect of temperature and WHSV on 1-butanol conversion and butenes selectivities were studied. The dehydration activity and selectivity of butenes were correlated with the characterization results to understand insights into the 1-butanol dehydration reaction. A plausible reaction mechanism of 1-butanol dehydration was also proposed based on the product distribution. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of 10 wt.% HPA/SiO2 catalysts 1.8 g of SiO2 (Loba Chemicals Pvt. Ltd.) was dispersed in 50 mL of methanol in a 100 mL round-bottomed flask and stirred for 10 min with a magnetic stirrer to make a suspension. The HPA (PTA, STA, PMA, and SMA*) solution was prepared by a dissolving 0.2 g of HPA in a small amount of water (5 mL), and then the solution was slowly added dropwise into the methanolic suspension of SiO2. The resulting solution was stirred for about 24 h at room temperature. Prior to analysis, a transparent circular wafer was made with a physical mixture of a definite amount of power sample and FT-IR grade KBr. All the spectra were taken against the KBr background acquired separately. The specific surface area and pore volume of different silica-supported HPA catalysts were determined using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm data collected at 77 K using Micromeritics ASAP2020 physisorption analyzer. Before the analysis, all the catalysts were degassed at 473 K for 5 h under vacuum (5 × 10−5 mmHg) in order to remove physically adsorbed impurities and moisture that may present. The specific surface area was calculated using adsorption isotherm data in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05–0.30 and the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The micropore area and micropore volume of the catalysts were calculated by the t-plot method. The average pore volume was considered as the volume of liquid nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 1.0 ca. Pore size distribution (PSD) was determined by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Pyridine IR spectra of the different silica-supported HPA catalysts were recorded in transmission mode with the spectrometer as mentioned above. Before the analysis, a few drops of pyridine were added to the finely grounded powder catalyst samples and kept under ambient conditions for several hours to ensure the adsorption of pyridine. The pyridine adsorbed catalysts were dried in an oven at 383 K for 1 h to remove the physisorbed pyridine. A transparent circular wafer was made using a mixture of pyridine adsorbed catalyst, and FTIR grade KBr and IR spectra were recorded in a similar way as mentioned above. The acidity of the different HPA catalysts was measured by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) using Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Before analysis, the sample was degassed at 473 K for 1 h under the flow of pure argon (20 mL/min) for the removal of residual moisture and impurities that may present, Then, the sample was cooled down to 373 K in flowing of Ar, and 10 vol% NH3-Ar gas mixture was introduced at a flow rate of 20 mL/min. The gas mixture flow was continued for 1 h, and the flow of gas was switched over to pure argon (50 mL/min for 1 h) to remove physisorbed ammonia from the catalyst surface and entire path. Then, the sample was heated up to 1073 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The amount of ammonia desorbed from the catalyst was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The surface area of the supported HPA catalysts was increased on the deposition of the 10 wt.% of respective HPA. The increase in surface area of SiO2 and other metal oxide supports on the deposition of HPA was also noticed earlier [35,55]. It was claimed that the deposition of HPA results in significant stabilization of the surface area. However, the BET surface area of the silica supported HPA catalysts was decreased with further increase in HPA loading for supported PTA and STA, as shown in Table 1. However, a slight decrease in surface area was noticed for supported PMA catalysts as the loading increased. The decrease in the surface area and pore volume with increasing HPA loading on silica was attributed to the blockage of pores because of the deposition of HPA [51,56]. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of pure silica and silica-supported HPA catalysts are depicted in Fig. 1 . The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of pure silica exhibits of the type IV isotherms based on IUPAC classification with sharp capillary condensation and well-defined hysteresis loop of the type H1, indicating the presence of a narrow distribution of cylindrical pores with an average pore size of ∼x223C 6.0 nm. In the case of supported HPA catalysts, the nitrogen adsorption isotherms patterns resemble type IV isotherms with an extended capillary condensation step from 0.4 to 1.0 relative pressure. The extended capillary condensations step (and absence of steep capillary condensations) indicates the presence of wide pore size distribution (PSD). The appearance of the H2 type hysteresis loop confirms the presence of ink bottle shape pores. All the supported HPA catalysts exhibited wide pore size distribution (3.0 to 6.0 nm), with an average value of ∼x223C 4 nm as shown in Fig. S2. 3.1.2 Powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD) The XRD patterns of the different silica-supported HPA catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The characteristic diffraction peaks observed for all HPA/SiO2 catalysts around 2θ value of 21.7–22.2° are assigned to amorphous silica. 10PTA/SiO2 did not show any diffraction peaks corresponding to Keggin-type structure because of the higher dispersion of PTA on silica, whereas 20PTA/SiO2 revealed characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 10.2°, 25.3°, 34.5°, and 37.5° corresponds to Keggin-type H3PW12O40 phase (PDF 75–2125) [57–59]. The IR bands at 802 cm−1 and 1091 cm−1 were assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric Si-O-Si stretching mode of vibrations, respectively [60]. The pure PTA of Keggin structure as reported in the literature exhibited four IR bands around 802 cm−1 (W-Oc-W, edge-sharing), 892 cm−1 (W-Ob-W, corner-sharing), 972 cm−1 (W = O, terminal) and 1075 cm−1 (P-O) [59,60]. In the present study, similar IR bands with Keggin structure features were observed for 10PTA/SiO2, 20PTA/SiO2, 10STA/SiO2, and 20STA/SiO2. The IR band at 802 cm−1 (symmetric Si-O-Si) was merged with W-Oc-W (edge-sharing) [53,56]. 3.1.4 NH3-TPD analysis The acid strengths and amount of acidity of the silica-supported HPA catalysts were determined by the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), and the results expressed in µmol of NH3 desorbed per gram of catalysts (µmol NH3/g) are shown in Fig. S4A and B & Fig. 3 . The desorption of ammonia for different HPA catalysts was observed in the two temperature ranges (373–510 K and 510–773 K). The broad desorption peak centered at 412–420 K is because of the presence of weak acid sites in all HPA catalysts. The bulk and supported HPA catalysts are associated with bound moisture and water of crystalline. The bulk and supported HPA catalysts undergo stage-wise dehydration process (removal of bound moisture and water of crystalline molecule) at different temperatures leading to evolution of different crystalline structures and even decomposition of HPA at relatively high temperature [53]. The removal of bound moisture happens around 373 K or even less. After that, the water of crystalline molecules releases gradually over a wide range of temperatures [53]. At high-temperature constitutional, water from HPA releases resulting deprotonation to its anhydride form, which is a thermally unstable phase causing decomposition of the material [53]. The TPD experiments without exposing the HPA catalyst to ammonia were performed for 20HPA/SiO2 catalysts to determine the amount of released water and/or decomposition of material, as shown in Fig. S4B. The ammonia desorbed over a wide temperature range of 510−773 K corresponding to strong acid sites was determined by subtracting the TCD signal of blank without NH3 from original TCD signal with NH3 of respective catalyst as shown in Fig. 3. The TPD profile of 20HPA/SiO2 with and without NH3 are shown in Fig. S4B. However, the contribution of material decomposition to the amount of NH3 desorbed cannot be ruled out and is difficult to estimate. The supported PMA exhibits good thermal stability among all the studied catalysts as a distinct desorption peak was not noticed at high temperature. Among all the supported HPA catalysts, 20STA/SiO2 exhibit the highest amount of desorbed NH3 leading to strong acid sites. Various aliphatic and olefinic gaseous hydrocarbons (C1 C5) and oxygenated compounds like di-n‑butyl ether (DBE), and butanal (BUN) were formed after dehydration of 1-butanol. The composition of butene isomers (iso-BUY, 1-BUY, cis-2-BUY, and trans-2-BUY) (Fig. S1) was varied with the reaction parameters and nature of acid sites (B/L ratio). Scheme 1 represents the plausible reaction pathway of selective dehydration of 1-butanol under studied reaction conditions. The conversion of 1-butanol takes place through two parallel pathways, dehydration and dehydrogenation, as shown in (Scheme 1). In the first pathway, 1-butanol dehydrated to 1-BUY over acid sites either directly or through the formation of an intermediate DBE. 1-BUY further isomerized to iso-BUY, cis-2-BUY, and trans-2-BUY isomers over the Brønsted acid sites [16,34]. The Brønsted acid site of the catalysts promoted the dehydration reaction and is followed by further isomerization of 1-BUY to other butene isomers [29,61]. In the second path, 1-butanol was dehydrogenated to BUN. Though the amount of BUN formed was very low and observed for the molybdenum (addenda atom) based supported HPA catalysts, which might be caused by Lewis acid sites or metallic center of the catalyst [16]. The oxophilic (Lewis acid sites) characteristics of molybdenum promote the adsorption of 1-butanol by coordinating with the oxygen atom of alcohol, leading to the formation of alkoxide species. Removal of alpha hydrogen resulted in the formation of BUN. Also, propylene and propane formation were observed with less than 1% selectivity. This result indicates that BUN was further converted to propylene and propane, respectively via dehydroformylation and decarbonylation reaction [16]. Formation of n-butane was noticed with a significant amount over silica-supported phospho/silicomolybdic acid catalysts. 1-BUY adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites forms cis-2-BUY and trans-2-BUY via double bond isomerization, whereas iso-BUY forms via skeletal isomerization of 1-BUY [4]. The formation of iso-BUY was negligible for the studied process and reaction parameters of the butanol dehydration reaction. The permanent gasses CO and H2 were not observed in the gaseous products. The formed CO might have undergone methanization reaction to form methane. Poor sensitivity of TCD may also limit the detection of CO and H2 which formed in minute quantities. For some catalysts, the formation of methane was observed with less than 0.5% selectivity. 3.3 Screening of different HPA catalysts The screening of the different silica-supported HPA catalysts for selective conversion of 1-butanol was performed at 623 K and WHSV of 15 h − 1 under ambient pressure. The results are presented in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . Among the studied supported HPA catalysts, PTA/SiO2 and STA/SiO2 exhibited higher 1-butanol conversion than PMA/SiO2 and SMA/SiO2 catalysts of similar HPA loading of 10 wt.%. The lowest 1-butanol conversion of 21% was obtained with 10PMA/SiO2 catalyst after 6 h time on stream (TOS). About 96% and 97% of 1-butanol conversion were achieved with 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts, respectively, after 6 h TOS. However, the 1-butanol conversion for 10PTA/SiO2 & 10STA/SiO2 was decreased to 79% and 75%, respectively. However, the selectivity to butenes was remained unchanged (Fig S5A and 5B). The decline in 1-butanol conversion is related to the decrease in the concentration of acid sites (Brønsted and Lewis sites) with a decrease in the HPA (PTA and STA) loading on SiO2, as shown in Fig. 4. The 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts were studied for 10 h of TOS as shown in Fig. S6. The activity of the 20PTA/SiO2 catalyst was dropped rapidly at and above 7 h of TOS. The decline of activity at higher TOS for 20PTA/SiO2 is related to its acid strength, water resistance, and thermal stability [52,62]. It was reported that the protonated form of STA is more thermally stable than the PTA in the temperature range of 573–773 K. PTA loses its protons at a lower temperature than STA. Moreover, supported STA exhibits higher resistance to water than the supported PTA, which is also an important factor for exhibiting higher activity [52]. Thus, the higher activity of 20STA/SiO2 is originated from higher acid strength and resistance to water. In order to take into account, the variation in surface area of supported HPA catalysts, the areal activity as defined in Eq. (3) was calculated for 20 wt.% HPA (SMA, PTA, STA, PMA) loading at 623 K reaction temperature and 15 h−1 of WHSV as shown in Fig. 6 . The higher areal activities and butenes selectivity were achieved for 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts. These results are well explained by correlating the B/L ratio of the catalysts with butanol conversion, as shown in Fig. 6. The 20SMA/SiO2 catalyst with the lowest B/L ratio showed less conversion, areal activity, and butenes selectivity (for 20wt% HPA loading on silica). In contrast, 20PMA/SiO2 with the highest B/L ratio showed less conversion, areal activity, and butenes selectivity compared to 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts. These results clearly indicate that the dehydration activity of HPA catalysts depends on the relative amount of both B and L sites. Thus, HPA catalysts with an appropriate B/L ratio is expected to exhibit higher dehydration activity and selectivity to butenes. The acidity of the catalyst is varied by changing the addenda atom and loading of HPA (Fig. 3 and S4A). The butanol conversion over 20PMA/SiO2, 10PMA/SiO2, and 20SMA/SiO2 catalysts was less than PTA/SiO2 and STA/SiO2 catalysts due to the absence of labile proton as discussed earlier. Moreover, the addendum atom molybdenum has redox and oxophilic properties and thereby promotes dehydrogenation reaction of 1-butanol to produce BUN. The formation of BUN confirms the dehydrogenation of 1-butanol. The BUN transforms into propane and propylene via dehydroformylation and decarbonylation reaction. The propane and butane may also form via hydrogenation of respective olefins. The lower activity of supported PMA catalyst may also be due to the partial reduction of molybdenum atom (Mo+6 to Mo+5). Partial reduction of molybdenum has been reported in the published literature [63]. The dehydration of 1-butanol over supported PTA and STA catalysts exhibited ∼x223C 100% selectivity towards butenes, as shown in Fig. 7 & Fig. S7. However, the formation of BUN, DBE, and n-butane was noticed over other supported HPA catalysts. The selectivity of butenes was decreased from 91.5% (Others: 6% n-butane, 0.9% BUN and 0.2% DBE) to 82% (Others: 3.3% n-butane, 6.3% BUN and 7% DBE) as the PMA loading decreased from 20 wt.% to 10 wt.%. This result indicates that dehydrogenation of 1-butanol was significant for lower PMA loading and decreased for higher PMA loading. In contrast, an opposite trend was observed for hydrogenation of 1-BUY, leading to the formation of n-butane. Among the butenes isomers, the selectivity of iso-BUY was almost negligible for all HPA catalysts. The skeleton isomerization of 1-BUY to 2-BUY varies with the loadings of HPA on silica. Higher loadings of PTA and STA enhanced the isomerization of 1-BUY to other 2-BUY isomers, which can be attributed to the higher acidity of these catalysts (Table S1). The selectivity of 1-BUY was decreased from 28.8% to 24.7%, whereas cis-2-BUY and trans-2-BUY selectivities were increased from 27.0% and 43.3% to 31.0% and 44.0%, respectively, with increasing in PTA loading from 10 wt.% to 20 wt.%. A similar trend was observed for supported STA catalysts as well. Therefore, at higher HPA loadings, isomerization of 1-BUY to cis-2-BUY and trans-2-BUY can be attributed to the higher amount of available Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 4). The selectivity of n-butane was higher over 10PMA/SiO2, 20PMA/SiO2, and 20SMA/SiO2 (3.3%, 6.0%, and 10.6%), which indicates enhanced hydrogenation of butenes to butanes over molybdenum (addenda atom) based supported HPA catalysts. The formation of C5 hydrocarbon suggests oligomerization of different olefins on acid sites present in the PMA and SMA catalysts. The conversion of 1-butanol was increased with the increase in reaction temperature from 523 K to 673 K over these catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8 & 9 . The 1-butanol conversion increased from 15.2% to 100% with the increase in temperature from 523 K to 673 K over 20 PTA/SiO2 catalyst. Whereas 1-butanol conversion was observed at different reaction temperatures over 20STA/SiO2 catalyst as follows: 51.0%, 59.9%, 77.6%, 91.4%, 93.0%, 93.7%, and 97.2% for 523 K, 548 K, 573 K, 598 K, 623 K, 648 K and 673 K, respectively. The butanol conversion observed at 523 K was higher over 20STA/SiO2 (51.0%) than 20 wt.% PTA/SiO2 (15.2%) catalyst attributed to the higher B/L ratio of the catalyst and the formation of lower DBE. As the reaction temperature increased, more active butanol molecules increased in the catalytic system, which enhanced the reaction rate, resulting in higher conversions. The selectivity for BUN observed at 523 K was nearly 0.5% and 0.4% over 20 PTA/SiO2 than 20STA/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. The formation of BUN was decreased with the increase in temperature, which might increase the rate of dehydration of butanol over these catalysts. The formation of propane and propylene was negligible for all the studied temperatures over these two catalysts, which further supports the higher rate of the dehydration reaction. Whereas the selectivity for DBE was observed as 18.8% and 2.8% at 523 K over 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts, respectively, and was decreased to 0% as the temperature was increased to 673 K. This result indicates that lower reaction temperature is favorable for the formation of DBE which is readily dehydrated to butenes with the temperature rise. It is understandable that the relative selectivity of 1-BUY was increased with the rise of temperature. This result explains that the isomerization of 1-BUY is favorable to low temperatures. The 1-BUY formed due to the dehydration of 1-butanol over acid sites isomerizes to form other butene isomers. As the temperature rises, 1-BUY desorbs readily from the catalyst surface, resulting in increasing in 1-BUY selectivity (Fig. S9 & S10). The conversion of 1-butanol was increased with decreasing in WHSV. The 1-butanol conversion increased from nearly 93.6% to 100%, with a decrease in WHSV from 299 h−1 to 37.4 h−1. The conversion remained virtually constant with the further decrease in WHSV beyond 37.4 h−1 for 20PTA/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S17). The lower conversion of 93.9% was obtained at 299 h−1 of WHSV and was increased to 98.9% at 7.5 h−1 of WHSV for 20STA/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S17). The lower conversion at higher WHSV was attributed to the lesser contact time of butanol molecules with the acid sites as compared to lower WHSV. Nonetheless, both the 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts exhibited more than 90% conversion at relatively high WHSV (299 h−1) in 6 h of TOS as shown in Fig. S18. It was reported that the higher 1-butanol conversion could be achieved at WHSV of less 2 h−1 and 623 K with a cumulative butenes selectivity of about 80% using γ-Al2O3 [18]. The higher activity of the HPA catalysts is attributed to the pseudo liquid phase behavior of these materials meaning the catalytic reaction takes place in the solid lattice (pseudo liquid phase catalysis) [43–45]. In the case of a polar molecule such as alcohol, amine, ether etc., the active sites in the surface and bulk phase (solid lattice phase) are potentially active for such polar compounds [43–45]. However, the pseudo liquid phase behavior is also influenced by the diffusional rate of the reactant and product molecules [43–45]. The diffusional rate is much slower at low temperature and of the order of liquid phase diffusivity. In the present investigation, the higher 1-butanol conversion and butenes selectivity even at high WHSV (299 h−1) is thereby ascribed to pseudo liquid phase behavior. However, diffusional effect may also play a strong role on the activity of HPA catalysts with pseudo liquid phase behavior at very high temperature and over wide range of WHSV. Thus, detailed studies on diffusional effect considering pseudo liquid phase behavior is important for the complete understanding of the activity of these catalysts over a wide range of WHSV and temperatures and can be regarded as the future scope of the present investigation. The higher butanol conversion was observed for the WHSV of 7.5 h−1, whereas butenes selectivity remained nearly constant at 99.8% in the studied WHSV range. 4 Conclusions The selective dehydration of 1-butanol to butenes over different silica-supported HPA catalysts has been studied in a continuous flow and isothermally operated fixed-bed reactor at different temperatures and WHSV to improve butanol conversion and butenes selectivity. The detailed characterization results indicate that increasing the HPA loading over silica support decreases the specific surface area and increases the strength of acidity and B/L ratio. The B/L ratio was observed to follow the order as follows: 20PMA/SiO2 > 20STA/SiO2 > 20PTA/SiO2 > 10PMA/SiO2 > 10STA/SiO2 > 10PTA/SiO2. The Brønsted acidity of PTA/SiO2 and STA/SiO2 catalysts was attributed to the proton lability resulted from the negative charge delocalization on W6+. Based on the dehydration activity, it was observed that the performance of different silica-supported HPA catalysts depends on the nature of HPA (addenda and hetero atom), the strength of acidity, nature of acid sites, and specific surface area. Higher areal activities and butenes selectivities were observed for the 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts. The time on stream studies indicate higher stability of 20STA/SiO2 catalyst and the higher activity of 20STA/SiO2 is originated from higher acid strength and resistance to water. Moreover, higher HPA loadings enhanced the 1-butanol conversion, selectivity of butenes, and isomerization of 1-BUY to other butene isomers. The reaction temperature and WHSV have a significant effect on butanol conversion and butenes selectivity. Higher temperatures enhanced the butanol dehydration and butenes selectivity over 20PTA/SiO2 and 20STA/SiO2 catalysts. 1-BUY was readily isomerized to other butene isomers as the reaction temperature decreases. Moreover, DBE was formed at low reaction temperature and was readily dehydrated to butenes at higher temperatures, increasing butenes selectivity. Low WHSV enhanced the butanol conversion, butenes selectivity, and 1-BUY isomerization due to increase contact time. The maximum butanol conversion and butenes selectivity were observed as ∼x223C 100% and 99.8% over 20PTA/SiO2 catalyst at 673 K and 37.4 h−1 of WHSV under atmospheric pressure. For 20STA/SiO2 catalyst, maximum butanol conversion and butenes selectivity were observed 98.9% and 99.8% at 673 K, 7.5 h−1 of WHSV under atmospheric pressure. coredata.dc:description: Butenes are considered as important olefinic building block to produce fuels/fuel additives and commodity chemicals. In the present investigation, selective dehydration of 1-butanol to butenes was studied in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor using various silica-supported heteropolyacid (HPA) catalysts such as phosphotungstic acid (PTA), silicotungstic acid (STA), phosphomolybdic acid (PMA), and silicomolybdic acid (SMA) as the solid acid catalysts. The physicochemical properties of these HPA were determined by BET, powder XRD, FTIR, NH3-TPD, and Py-FTIR. The acid strength and Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) acid ratio were increased with higher loading of HPA on silica. The nature of HPA (addenda and hetero atom) and loading of HPA are important factors for the dehydration of 1-butanol and selectivity towards butenes. PTA and STA showed superior catalytic activity than PMA and SMA. The reaction temperature and WHSV also strongly affected the butanol conversion and selectivity of butenes. The selectivity of di-n‑butyl ether decreases with the rising temperature from 523 K to 623 K. The isomerization of 1-butene leading to the formation of other butene isomers depends on the HPA loading, temperature, and WHSV. The presence of molybdenum addendum atom in PMA and SMA promotes dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, leading to the formation of various light hydrocarbons. The 20PTA/SiO2 catalyst afforded 99.8% selectivity towards butenes at quantitative conversion of 1-butanol, whereas the 20STA/SiO2 catalyst gave nearly 97.0% conversion of 1-butanol and 99.9% butenes selectivity at 673 K, 37.4 h−1 of WHSV.
